<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct WsData *ws = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = ws->urh;
  unsigned char buf[2048];
  unsigned char *msg;
  char *text;
  ssize_t got;
  int type;
  int i;

  make_blocking (ws->sock);
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (ws->sock, (void *) buf, sizeof (buf), 0);
    if (0 >= got)
    {
      break;
    }
    msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
    if (NULL == msg)
    {
      break;
    }
    if (type == WS_OPCODE_TEXT_FRAME)
    {
      ssize_t sent;
      int buf_size;
      buf_size = snprintf (NULL, 0, "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg);
      if (0 < buf_size)
      {
        text = malloc ((size_t) buf_size + 1);
        if (NULL != text)
        {
          if (snprintf (text, (size_t) buf_size + 1,
                        "User#%d: %s", (int) ws->sock, msg) == buf_size)
            sent = ws_send_frame (ws->sock, text, (size_t) buf_size);
          else
            sent = -1;
          free (text);
        }
        else
          sent = -1;
      }
      else
        sent = -1;
      free (msg);
      if (-1 == sent)
      {
        break;
      }
    }
    else
    {
      if (type == WS_OPCODE_CON_CLOSE_FRAME)
      {
        free (msg);
        break;
      }
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_lock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  for (i = 0; i < MAX_CLIENTS; i++)
  {
    if (CLIENT_SOCKS[i] == ws->sock)
    {
      CLIENT_SOCKS[i] = MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
      break;
    }
  }
  if (0 != pthread_mutex_unlock (&MUTEX))
    abort ();
  free (ws);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh, MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
msg = ws_receive_frame (buf, &got, &type);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: If ws_receive_frame does not modify the input buffer and returns data that the caller only reads, then both the parameter and the returned pointer should be const-qualified. In the code fragment msg = ws_receive_frame(buf, &got, &type); msg is declared as unsigned char * (non-const) and buf is passed as a non-const array; this permits modification even if none is intended. Thus if ws_receive_frame merely reads buf and returns a read-only pointer, the correct form would be e.g. const unsigned char *ws_receive_frame(const unsigned char *buf, ssize_t *got, int *type); and msg should be const unsigned char *msg; failing to use const in that case violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Note: if ws_receive_frame actually returns heap memory that the caller must free or the caller is expected to modify the returned data, then const would not be appropriate and no violation would occur.
